content.text: The Machakhela project in Georgia serves as a blueprint for replicable and adaptable strategies in sustainable energy development. Key elements such as energy diversification, robust regulatory frameworks, public-private partnerships, and investments in modern infrastructure and technology ensure energy security and efficiency. Successful replication requires strong governmental commitment, suitable natural resources, and a conducive regulatory environment. Scalable training programs and community engagement initiatives are vital for widespread adoption, while investments in infrastructure and policy integration ensure long-term sustainability. By understanding local needs, forging strong partnerships, and employing flexible funding models, similar projects can be effectively implemented across different regions, contributing to global efforts towards sustainable energy transition. Sustainability and future directions for the project hinge on continuous community engagement and ownership, facilitated through local committees or cooperatives overseeing maintenance. Ongoing technical support and monitoring, including the integration of digital tools, ensure effectiveness. Advocacy for supportive policies, scaling up initiatives based on lessons learned, and ongoing research into renewable energy technologies are crucial for long-term impact and adaptation to diverse contexts, fostering environmental conservation and sustainable development globally.

content.title: THE IMPACT OF ENERGY SYSTEMS ON CLIMATE CHANGE
content.intro: M6: The Climate Change-Energy Nexus | Chapter 1 | Lesson 1

content.title: Key Concepts
content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: circular economy
concepts.body: A circular economy is an economic system aimed at eliminating waste and the continual use of resources by reusing, recycling, and regenerating materials, creating a closed-loop system that minimizes environmental impact.

concepts.title: climate change scenario analysis
concepts.body: Climate change scenario analysis is a method used to evaluate potential future impacts of climate change by exploring different possible scenarios based on varying levels of greenhouse gas emissions, policy responses, and socio-economic developments.

concepts.title: decarbonization
concepts.body: Decarbonization is the process of reducing or eliminating carbon dioxide emissions from energy sources and industrial processes to combat climate change.

content.text: Lesson 1 Overview

The current energy system is a major driver of global climate change, accounting for around 75% of total greenhouse gas emissions. This means transforming how we produce and consume energy is essential, with the world’s ability to meet its climate goals hinging on the energy sector’s ability to decarbonize and to keep global warming to no more than 1.5°C – as called for in the Paris Agreement – emissions need to be reduced by 45% by 2030 and reach net zero by 2050. As temperatures break records year after year, the case for action has never been stronger.

content.intro: M6: The Climate Change-Energy Nexus | Chapter 1 | Lesson 1 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: Emissions Breakdown

content.text: Part 1 Overview

Reliable, accurate, and timely data are essential for crafting evidence-based energy policies that drive sustainable development. Without quality data, policy decisions risk being misinformed, leading to ineffective solutions or unintended consequences. According to the International Recommendations for Energy Statistics (UN, 2018), data must meet five critical dimensions of quality to effectively support sound decision-making, as introduced on the next page..

The energy sector emissions include electricity and heat generation (29.7%), transportation (13.7%), manufacturing and construction (12.7%), and buildings (6.6%). Fugitive emissions (those released during fossil fuel production or transmission) and emissions from other fuel combustion are also significant contributors. Residential buildings represent the largest share of energy sector emissions, contributing 12.5% to global emissions. This includes emissions from electricity generation for household use and direct fossil fuel consumption, such as cooking with gas. Road transportation is another major source, accounting for 12.2% of global emissions.

Since 1990, the three emissions sources within the energy sector that have grown the fastest are: electricity and heating, which grew by 88%; transportation, which grew by 66%; and manufacturing and construction, which grew by 60%. By contrast, non-energy sectors collectively contribute only one-quarter of global emissions, highlighting the critical need to focus on decarbonizing the energy sector.
GHG Emissions from Energy Production

Combustion plays a major role in energy production, especially for power generation and heating. Over 40% of energy-related CO2 emissions come from burning fossil fuels for electricity. In 2022 alone, CO2 emissions from energy combustion grew by 1.3% (423 Mt). However, energy-related greenhouse gas emissions arise from a range of sources beyond combustion, including fugitive methane emissions from oil and gas operations and process emissions from industrial activities. CO2 emissions from energy combustion and industrial processes accounted for 89% of energy-related greenhouse gas emissions in 2022. Total energy-related greenhouse gas emissions increased by 1.0% to an all-time high of 41.3 Gt CO2-eq.

Key factors driving CO2 emissions from electricity generation include how much electricity is produced, the efficiency of generation, the reliance on fossil fuels, and the carbon intensity of those fuels. Specifically, coal-fired power plants were the biggest contributors, responsible for 73% of electricity-sector CO2 emissions. While carbon dioxide (CO2) is the most abundant greenhouse gas, the energy sector also emits non-CO2 greenhouse gases like methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O) and and sulfur hexafluoride (SF₆). These gases, although emitted in smaller quantities, have much higher global warming potentials and different atmospheric lifespans, making them critical to address in climate strategies.

Methane, the second-largest driver of global warming after CO2, is a significant concern in the energy sector. Oil and gas operations are the biggest sources of methane emissions, while incomplete combustion of bioenergy—like wood, charcoal, and crop residues—adds to methane emissions. Methane is released both intentionally, through practices like venting and flaring during production and maintenance, and accidentally, through leaks in pipelines, compressors, and valves (fugitive emissions).
GHG Emissions from Energy Production

Energy distribution contributes to GHG emissions through the transportation of energy from production sites to end-users. This includes emissions from transporting fuels, building and maintaining infrastructure, and operating energy distribution networks. Apart from these, the inefficiencies inherent in the distribution process add to the GHG emissions. In fact, energy losses during transportation are significant, with approximately 19 exajoules (EJ) lost annually in the process. They represent a dual challenge: wasted energy that could otherwise power economies and the associated emissions resulting from generating that wasted energy. These losses equate to roughly $200 billion each year.

A key source of emissions in the transmission and distribution of electricity is sulfur hexafluoride (SF₆). It is used as an insulating gas in high-voltage electrical equipment such as switchgear and circuit breakers and is the most potent greenhouse gas regulated under the Kyoto Protocol. Its GWP is about 25,200 times greater than CO₂, and even small leaks during equipment operation, maintenance, or decommissioning can significantly impact emissions. As a result, addressing SF₆ emissions through better leak detection, maintenance practices, and alternative technologies, has become an important focus in reducing the climate impact of energy distribution networks.
GHG Emissions from Energy Production

Energy consumption spans four primary sectors: industry, buildings, transport, and others (including agriculture and non-energy uses). In this breakdown, emissions from electricity and heat generation are allocated to the sectors that ultimately consume them, rather than being reported separately. This approach captures both direct emissions (from burning fuels on-site) and indirect emissions (from purchased electricity and heat), providing a clearer picture of each sector’s total impact. After allocating electricity and heat emissions to their final use, the industry remained the largest emitting sector in 2022, contributing nearly 38% of global fuel combustion emissions. Buildings followed at 26%, with transport accounting for 24%, and the remaining emissions coming from other sectors.

Specifically, buildings are a significant source of emissions due to their construction and increasing operational energy demands for heating, cooling, lighting, and equipment. In 2022, energy-related emissions from building operations reached 10 gigatonnes of CO2 equivalent, a 5% increase from 2020 levels and 2% higher than the pre-pandemic peak in 2019. In 2022, direct CO2 emissions from buildings such as those from on-site fossil fuel combustion for space and water heating or cooking decreased slightly. However, indirect emissions, primarily from electricity use for lighting, cooling systems, and appliances, increased. This highlights the growing reliance on electricity in buildings.

Regional trends varied, with emissions declining in some areas and increasing in others, often influenced by factors like weather conditions. Achieving the IEA’s Net Zero Emissions (NZE) Scenario requires emissions from buildings to fall by an unprecedented 9% annually until 2030, which is a colossal challenge. High-income countries face the task of retrofitting existing buildings, while lower-income countries are grappling with the emissions implications of rapid new construction. These distinct challenges also present unique opportunities for innovation in energy efficiency and sustainable building practices.

content.intro: M6: The Climate Change-Energy Nexus | Chapter 1 | Lesson 1 | Part 2
content.title: Part 2: Impacts of Renewable Energy Development on Ecosystems

content.text: This section builds on Module 3 by exploring the specific impacts of renewable energy technologies on ecosystems and strategies to mitigate them. While renewables are essential for reducing emissions, their development can disrupt habitats and biodiversity if not carefully managed. Here, we examine these challenges in greater detail and explore solutions such as sustainable siting, ecological safeguards, and integrated approaches to ensure a truly sustainable energy transition.
Land Use Conflicts

The land requirements for different energy generation methods vary significantly, especially when considering their entire life cycle. Life-cycle land use assessments account not only for the physical footprint of the energy plant itself but also for the land required for activities like mining materials for construction, sourcing fuel inputs, decommissioning, and managing waste. The construction of renewable energy facilities, such as solar farms and wind turbines, requires significantly more land to produce the same amount of electricity as a coal-fired power plant. This can lead to habitat fragmentation and displacement of wildlife.

Ground mounted solar installations tend to have relatively high land use, although this varies based on location and the configuration of the solar panels. For instance, utility-scale solar farms, unlike rooftop solar panels, can disrupt local ecosystems by occupying large tracts of land, altering habitats, and driving species away from their natural environments. While it is true that rooftop solar installations use significantly less land, as they utilize existing structures, their land use is not zero, as mining materials for solar panel production still require land resources.

A study analyzing solar energy land use in regions like the European Union, India, and South Korea highlight a key concern: as solar energy becomes a larger share of a region's electricity mix, associated land-use changes and emissions also grow. Solar expansion often takes place on land currently used for agriculture or forestry. This displacement can push agricultural or forestry activities to other areas, often involving unused arable land, resulting in natural land cover losses. These changes disturb local ecosystems and release carbon stored in soils and vegetation, offsetting some of the environmental benefits of solar energy.

Another study on a 96 MW solar installation in South Africa found a significant decline in bird species diversity and density. The replacement of the natural savanna with solar panels and managed grasslands disrupted habitats, reducing nesting and foraging opportunities for local bird populations. These land-use challenges also intersect with social considerations, particularly in the context of achieving a just energy transition (previously discussed in Module 3). Large-scale projects can have varied impacts on local communities, raising concerns about equitable access to opportunities and minimizing risks for those most affected by renewable energy expansion. Understanding the broader implications of land use in renewable energy development is crucial for designing sustainable energy strategies that minimize ecological and social impacts.
Infrastructure Development

The infrastructure required for renewable energy projects can also impact local ecosystems and livelihoods. Wind farms can pose threats to birds and bats due to collisions with turbine blades, while hydroelectric projects can disrupt aquatic habitats and alter water flow patterns. Nevertheless, research and conservation efforts are underway to identify best practices for developing energy infrastructure in a way that minimizes damage to biodiversity and ecosystem services.
Mining for Renewable Resources

The transition to renewable energy necessitates increased mining activities for essential materials like lithium, cobalt, and rare earth elements. Mining operations often result in severe environmental degradation, including soil erosion, water pollution, and destruction of habitats. In fact, many reserves of critical minerals for renewable power infrastructure coincide with areas of high biodiversity value. In regions where these minerals are extracted, such as the Atacama Desert in Chile, mining activities have been attributed to being one of the major stressors to local environmental degradation. Similarly, in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), home to one of the world’s largest rainforests, cobalt mining has raised major environmental and human rights concerns, including deforestation, water contamination, and child labor. Deep sea mining is also being explored to meet mineral demand, targeting resources on the ocean floor. However, it poses serious risks to marine ecosystems, including habitat destruction and loss of biodiversity, raising concerns about its environmental impact.
Managing the Full Lifecycle of Renewable Energy Infrastructure

The decommissioning of renewable energy infrastructure is an often-overlooked challenge that has long-term implications for energy systems and sustainability. Wind turbines, solar panels, and hydropower facilities all have finite lifespans; typically 20-30 years for solar panels and wind turbines, and up to 100 years for hydropower plants. For offshore wind farms, decommissioning involves dismantling turbines, removing subsea structures, and managing waste materials. Without proper planning, this process could disrupt marine ecosystems and create large quantities of waste. Similarly, solar panel disposal raises concerns about e-waste and the recycling of rare materials like silicon, silver, and cadmium. Hydropower plants, especially older ones, may require retrofitting or removal, which can significantly impact water systems and local ecosystems. A lack of decommissioning strategies could lead to stranded assets and increased environmental impacts.

content.intro: M6: The Climate Change-Energy Nexus | Chapter 1 | Lesson 1 | Part 3
content.title: Part 3: The Need for Sustainable Practices

content.text: Part 3 Overview
To mitigate the negative impacts of land use changes associated with the energy transition, several strategies can be implemented. A few of them are discussed next.
Site Selection

Prioritizing the development of renewable energy projects on degraded or previously disturbed lands rather than pristine ecosystems can help minimize habitat destruction. Utilizing rooftops or brownfield sites for solar installations is one approach that reduces land-use conflicts.
Prioritize Degraded Lands

Focusing on the development of renewable energy projects on degraded or previously disturbed lands rather than pristine ecosystems is crucial. This strategy minimizes habitat destruction and helps preserve biodiversity. For instance, utilizing rooftops or brownfield sites for solar installations can significantly reduce land-use conflicts and environmental degradation.
Avoid High-Conflict Areas

Siting policies should exclude high-yield cropland and other ecologically sensitive areas to limit land competition and adverse impacts. Instead, regions such as deserts or dry scrublands, which are less suitable for agriculture and human activities, should be prioritized for solar energy installations.
Incorporate Local Ecological Considerations

Effective spatial planning that includes ecosystem and wildlife sensitivity mapping is essential. Identifying "Renewables Acceleration Areas" through rigorous assessments can help balance renewable energy development with ecological preservation. This involves considering local community needs and potential conflicts to ensure sustainable project siting.
Integrated Planning

Incorporating biodiversity considerations into energy planning processes is essential. This includes assessing the potential ecological impacts of proposed projects and implementing measures to protect sensitive habitats.
Conduct Comprehensive Environmental Assessments

Before initiating any renewable energy project, it is crucial to conduct thorough environmental impact assessments (EIAs). These assessments should evaluate potential ecological impacts, including effects on local wildlife, plant species, and overall ecosystem health.
Utilize Geospatial Analysis

Employing geospatial tools and technologies can help in mapping sensitive habitats and biodiversity hotspots. This information can guide site selection and project design, ensuring that developments avoid critical areas and minimize disruptions to local ecosystems.
Implement Mitigation Strategies

For projects that may impact sensitive habitats, it is important to develop and implement mitigation strategies. These could include habitat restoration efforts, creating wildlife corridors, or establishing conservation easements to protect affected areas.
Engage Stakeholders

Involving local communities, conservation organizations, and other stakeholders in the planning process is vital. Their insights can provide valuable perspectives on biodiversity concerns and help identify areas of ecological significance that may not be readily apparent through standard assessments.

Innovative practices are emerging to address these land-use conflicts. Agrivoltaics, for example, combines solar energy production with agricultural activities, allowing crops to be grown beneath or between solar panels. Agrivoltaic systems are being implemented in Kenya, Tanzania, and Uganda, where the shade provided by solar panels helps shield crops from extreme heat and minimizes water evaporation from both plants and soil. This approach has led to improved yields and healthier crops, including cabbage, eggplant, lettuce, and maize. Additionally, pollinator-friendly solar farms are gaining traction. These involve planting wildflowers and native vegetation under and around solar panels to support pollinators, improve soil quality, and preserve the land for potential future agricultural use. Such solutions help balance the expansion of solar energy with environmental conservation and sustainable land management.
Green Production Inputs and Processes

Incorporating green production and responsible practices into renewable energy supply chains is essential. This involves sourcing low-carbon materials and adopting sustainable manufacturing techniques to minimize emissions and waste.
Implement Cradle-to-Cradle Design

Adopting a cradle-to-cradle* approach in manufacturing focuses on designing products that can be fully reclaimed or recycled at the end of their life cycle. This minimizes waste and promotes the use of materials that can be continuously repurposed, thereby reducing the demand for new raw materials. *Cradle to cradle can be defined as the design and production of products of all types in such a way that at the end of their life, they can be truly recycled (upcycled), imitating nature’s cycle with everything either recycled or returned to the earth, directly or indirectly through food, as a completely safe, nontoxic, and biodegradable nutrient.
Switch to Renewable Energy Sources & Enhance Energy Efficiency

Powering manufacturing processes with renewable energy—such as solar, wind, or geothermal—can significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Moreover, upgrading to smart lighting systems, optimizing heating and cooling systems, and using advanced manufacturing techniques that minimize energy consumption can help improve energy efficiency.
Reduce, Reuse, Recycle

Establishing robust recycling programs and initiatives to reduce waste is crucial in green manufacturing. Companies should conduct waste audits to identify recyclable materials and implement practices that minimize waste generation during production.
Focus on Pollution Reduction

Adopting processes that limit the release of pollutants into the environment is essential. This can involve using non-toxic materials and cleaner production techniques that reduce harmful emissions and improve overall environmental performance.
Restoration Efforts
Alongside energy development, efforts should be made to restore degraded ecosystems. Reforestation initiatives can help recover lost habitats and enhance carbon sequestration capabilities.

content.intro: M6: The Climate Change-Energy Nexus | Chapter 1 | Lesson 1 | Part 3 | Case Study
content.title: Case Study: Georgia

content.text: Case Study RBEC: RENEWABLE ENERGY PRACTICES FOR SUSTAINABLE FOREST MANAGEMENT AND ENHANCED COMMUNITY RESILIENCE

The initiative focuses on implementing energy-efficient technologies and renewable energy practices in Georgia's Machakhela Protected Landscape, as a part of the Climate Promise global framework. Funded by the Government of Japan, the project aims to safeguard the Colchic forest ecosystem in Machakheli Valley by introducing energy-efficient technologies like solar panels and water heaters in local communities while tackling the hazards of forest degradation brought on by over-exploitation of fuelwood, climate change, and global challenges.

The project aimed to enhance the protection of the forests, reduce climate change-associated risks and enable access to clean and affordable energy. Solar water heaters and photovoltaic panels were selected as primary technologies, and training sessions and digital monitoring tools were provided. 200 heaters and 70 panels were procured, followed by targeted installation in vulnerable households. A feasibility study on biomass production was conducted, leveraging Japanese partners' expertise. Awareness-raising activities, supported by local NGOs, promoted the benefits of renewable energy. A monitoring system tracked key metrics like energy savings, fuelwood reduction, and emissions decreases. Partnerships with the Ministry of Agriculture, Khelvachauri Municipality, Machakhela National Park, UNDP's Country Office, and the Ministry of Environmental Protection and Agriculture ensured coordinated, policy-aligned implementation.

Over 3000 residents, mostly women, benefit from this effort, increasing access to renewable energy, reducing climate risks, and improving forest protection. It has led to an annual reduction of approximately 900 cubic meters of fuelwood usage, saving around 300 trees annually. This reduction in CO2 emissions and carbon sequestration enhances the forests' capacity to sequester carbon, protecting biodiversity and mitigating climate change.
The bio-energy roadmap of Georgia

The initiative has improved the lives of approximately 1,350 people in vulnerable families in the Machakhela Protected Landscape area, providing access to clean and affordable energy, reducing energy costs, and improving living conditions, particularly for women and female household caretakers. The project has given women more economic power, allowing them to take on more productive roles in the local economy and lessening family obligations. Despite challenges such as limited forest resources, climate-driven disasters, logistical hurdles, and political instability, the project overcame these obstacles through robust partnerships, UNDP's operational framework, and a strong commitment to community engagement, educational workshops, participatory planning, capacity-building programs, and collaborative resource management. Workshops educated residents, particularly women, on renewable energy and sustainable technologies, such as solar panels and biogas units. These engagement strategies not only addressed challenges like limited forest resources and political instability but also enhanced community resilience and improved the well-being of the local population.

Georgia is making progress in enacting laws and policies to monitor and decrease greenhouse gas emissions, and the EU and UNDP are assisting the country in refining its climate and energy policy. By providing reliable, clean energy sources and promoting sustainable practices, the project reduced pressure on the Colchic forest ecosystems and enhanced the resilience and well-being of the local population. The successful implementation of renewable energy technologies and sustainable solutions relies on community engagement, particularly involving local populations, women and vulnerable groups. Comprehensive training and education on the use and maintenance of technologies like solar water heaters and photovoltaic panels empower beneficiaries, enhancing sustainability and effective utilization. The strategy for the project is based on lessons acquired from the Fuelwood Alternative Pilot Programme, which was undertaken as part of the UNDP-GEF Adjara Protected Areas project and the EU ENPARD rural development program. Pilot programs provide valuable insights and allow for adjustments before broader implementation. These initiatives promise tangible benefits for both the local communities and the environment. By transitioning to renewable energy, Machakheli Valley is poised to save up to 900 m3 of fuelwood annually, preserving 300 trees and mitigating 7 tons of CO2 emissions per year. This project aligns with Georgia's commitment to the Paris Agreement, aiming to increase forest carbon-capturing capacity by 10 percent and reduce national greenhouse gas emissions by 30-35 percent by 2030, in comparison to 2015 and 1990 levels respectively.
References

1. GIZ, Supporting Climate friendly forest management in Georgia 2. IEA, A Bioenergy map of Georgia 3. UNDP, Project Document – Georgia 4. New direction, Georgia and the EU - Together Towards Environmental and Climate Resilience 5. Georgia Trend, Georgia grid resiliency and clean energy project

content.title: Learning Objectives
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

objectives.title: Monitoring progress towards sustainable energy goals is key.
objectives.description: Examine the significant contribution of energy systems to global greenhouse gas emissions and evaluate the pathways for transitioning to net-zero energy production and consumption by mid-century.

objectives.title: Economic growth and energy policies are critical.
objectives.description: Assess the vulnerabilities of energy infrastructure to climate-related risks, including extreme weather events and long-term climate stressors, and identify strategies to mitigate these challenges.

objectives.title: We must always be evaluating the environmental impact of sustainable energy development.
objectives.description: Evaluate the role of renewable energy technologies and other sustainable solutions in decarbonizing the end-use sectors, considering their environmental, economic, and social implications.
